In this communication, we report on successfully applying a high-valent Ru(IV) bifunctional catalyst (1) for the hydrosilylation of carbonyl compounds, carboxylic acids, esters, nitriles, and nitroarenes. We found that high-valent hydride complexes can be regarded as “hard” nucleophiles, unlike more conventional low-valent counterparts. They demonstrate high chemoselectivity and affinity to reducing polar bonds over nonpolar ones. The scope and limitations of the method, as well as the plausible mechanism of the reaction, are described. Keywords high-valent ruthenium pincer complexes cooperative catalysis hydrosilylation of esters Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction Catalytic hydrosilylation of carbonyl and carboxyl compounds with alkyl silanes is a versatile reduction method allowing the direct synthesis of silyl ether-protected alcohols in a single step [1]. Hydrosilylation often proceeds under mild conditions that tolerate a large spectrum of functional groups [2]. Moreover, owing to the nonpolar nature of the Si-H bonds and the easy-to-handle physical state of the silane reagents, it represents a safe alternative to conventional hydrogenation, obviating the use of highly flammable metal hydrides or pressurized molecular hydrogen and thus, avoiding the need for special techniques [3,4]. Like conventional catalytic hydrogenation, the field of hydrosilylation is dominated by electron-rich precious or earth-abundant metal catalysts in a low oxidation state, which are more susceptible to oxidative addition, the prerequisite mechanistic step in H-H and H-Si activation [5–11]. Paradoxically, this statement is also true for transition metal catalysts that operate via alternative nonoxidative Si-H bond activation mechanisms that, for example, cleave bonds via metal-ligand cooperative mechanism (i.e., splitting them heterolytically between a Lewis acidic metal and a Lewis basic ligand) [12–16], π-acidic catalysis [17,18], or other mechanisms that do does not require electron-rich metals [19–24]. In contrast, using high-valent metal complexes for hydrogenation and hydrosilylation reactions is rare. For example, the first precedent was reported by Toste and co-workers, who demonstrated the hydrosilylation of aldehydes and ketones with the air-stable dioxorhenium(V) catalyst that mediates hydrosilylation by an unprecedented MLC mechanism involving the addition of silane across a ReO oxo bond [25,26]. Following these seminal publications, Royo extended this reactivity to molybdenum (VI) and rhenium (VII) dioxo compounds [27,28]. More recently, Saito demonstrated phosphine-modified rhenium (V) oxo complex as a catalyst in the direct hydrogenation of carboxylic acids (Fig. 1 ) [29,30]. For non-oxo complexes, our group recently reported on the first high-valent Ru(IV) pincer catalyst (1) for mild activation of hydrogen and hydrogenation of carbonyl, carboxyl, and carbonate compounds (Fig. 1, right) [31,32]. We demonstrated that despite a widely accepted concept of hydrogenation catalysis traditionally employing low-oxidation state transition metal species, non-oxo high-valent metals are also viable candidates for designing hydrogenation catalysts. Moreover, their reactivity is strikingly different from the described for oxo-compounds[26] and the low-valent analogs from the same class of pincer complexes [33–38] – it involves a nonoxidative H-H-bond cleavage by a highly electrophilic Ru(IV) center and a peripheral hydroxyl group [32]. In this communication, we report on the successful application of this catalytic system for activating silanes and hydrosilylating aldehydes, ketones, esters, carboxylic acids, nitriles, and nitroarenes and shed light on the mechanism of the catalytic reaction. Results and discussion Catalytic tests. The complexes described in this study have been prepared as we described previously [31]. To test the capability of the high-valent catalyst in hydrosilylation reactions, we started with esters recognized for their challenging reducibility. As an initial step, we carried out experiments utilizing 4-methylbenzyl 4-chlorobenzoate as a model substrate, allowing us to evaluate all possible products quantitatively. First, we examined different types of silanes while using 1 mol% of the pre-catalyst 1 in THF (1 mL) at 130 °C for 20 hours. Et2SiH2, Et3SiH, iPr3SiH, Me2SiH2, and PhSiH3 were tested (Table 1 ). After brief experimentation, we found that the best yield of the corresponding 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol was obtained using PhSiH3 (96%, entry 5), followed by Et2SiH2 with 88% yield (entry 4). Other tested silanes, such as Et3SiH, iPr3SiH, and Me2SiH2, exhibited poor reactivity, leading to ester hydrolysis on account of the desired hydrogenation products (entries 1-3). Next, our attempts to improve the catalyst performance by replacing THF with another solvent (e.g., toluene, dioxane, or acetonitrile) or carrying out the reaction under solvent-free conditions (entries 6-8) led to less encouraging results. Similarly, reducing the catalyst load to 0.5 mol% or reaction temperature also resulted in lower yields. (Table 1, entries 9-10). Finally, the superior activity of the high-valent 1 versus a low-valent 2 under the same reaction conditions stressed the importance of the higher oxidation state of the catalytic metal for activating the H-Si bond (entry 11). The optimal reaction conditions were then applied to the hydrosilylation of a range of substrates (Table 2 ) [39–43]. We were glad to realize that in addition to benzyl benzoates, less reactive alkyl esters were reduced efficiently under the same reaction conditions independently of the size of the alkyl group. Thus, the methyl, ethyl, and isopropyl benzoates were reduced in 97, 98, and 95% yield, respectively (entries 1-3). Remarkably, no dehalogenation of the brominated and chlorinated esters, a widespread side reaction, was detected, emphasizing the high chemoselectivity of the method (entries 4-5). Finally, hydrosilylation of the aliphatic benzyl acetate was accomplished with excellent yield (table 2, entry 6). Moreover, we found that catalyst 1 is capable of reducing even unprotected benzoic acids under the same reaction conditions. This reaction is a valuable extension of the scope of our catalyst because carboxylic acids are prevalent functional groups that originate from fossils, natural products, and synthetic intermediates. On the other hand, their hydrogenation is a versatile method for forming alcohols. Unfortunately, unlike esters, unprotected carboxylic acids are relatively unreactive electrophiles [44], limiting their employment as common alcohol precursors to a limited number of catalytic systems [45–51]. Thus, various differently substituted benzoic acids were cleanly converted to benzyl alcohols under hydrosilylation conditions catalyzed by 1. Also, no dehalogenation was observed when para, meta, and ortho-chlorinated substrates were employed (entries 8-9 and 11-12). Here again, the reactivity of the low-valent 1 was significantly lower than the high-valent 2, which supports Saito's hypothesis that harder high-valent catalytic metals are advantageous for hydrogenating less reactive carboxylic acids (entries 1, 3, 6, 8 and 10) [29]. Following the same idea, we undertook attempts to hydrosilylate other challenging substrates, namely, benzonitriles [52,53] and nitroarenes [54–56], because the products of their reduction, anilines, and benzylamines, are common intermediates for synthesizing fine chemicals, including biologically active molecules, natural products, dyes, agrochemicals, and raw chemicals [57]. Among others, their reduction can be catalytically performed using molecular hydrogen as a reductant [58–61]. Alternatively, catalytic or non-catalytic reduction systems use (over)stoichiometric reducing agents such as metallic zinc, iron, sulfides, metal hydrides, or hydrazines. Although these methods do not require special high-pressure equipment, these systems are hazardous and environmentally expensive [62–75]. Consequently, silanes appear as more environment-friendly reductants. Unfortunately, homogeneous transfer hydrogenation and hydrosilylation methods utilizing iron [76], ruthenium [77], cobalt [78], and molybdenum [79] catalysts are rare. In addition, chemoselectivity issues such as incomplete reductions to hydroxylamines or azocompounds often accompany the desired reductions [80–83]. Gratifyingly, the representative substrates shown in Table 3 have been reduced to the corresponding amines in excellent yield and selectivity. Finally, aldehydes and ketones [84–86], the more activated substrates, were hydrosilylated to their corresponding alcohols under a reduced load of 1 and at a lower reaction temperature and time (Table 4 ). For example, the complete conversion of acetophenone to 2-phenyl ethanol was achieved using only 0.5 mol% of 1 at 80 (C in THF after 10 hours (entry 1). Substrates possessing different functional groups, such as methyl-, methoxy-, halides, and heteroaromatic rings, were also reduced chemoselectively and in excellent isolated yield (entries 2-6). Remarkably, hydrogenation of carvone and 1,2,3,6-tetrahydrobenzaldehyde resulted in the formation of 1,6-dihydrocarveol and cyclohex-3-en-1-ylmethanol, respectively, as sole products (entries 7-8). At the same time, the low-valent catalyst 2 led to the over-hydrogenated products. This unusual chemoselectivity indicates that while conjugated double bonds are reduced, the isolated nonpolar double bonds remain unchanged under these reaction conditions, stressing the difference in reactivity between the high-valent and low-valent catalysts. We suspect that the tolerance of the high-valent hydrogenation catalysts toward isolated double bonds originates from the harder nature of the Ru(IV) hydride, which favors more polar electrophiles [87]. The plausible mechanism of the Ru(IV)-H formation under hydrogen pressure conditions was studied in the past [31,32]. We demonstrated experimentally and theoretically that H2 activation occurs under highly basic conditions and via a long-range ligand metal-ligand cooperating mechanism where deprotonation of the peripheral hydroxyl sidearm is responsible for the heterolytic H-H cleavage (Scheme 2). However, the Ru(IV)-H formation in the presence of hydrosilanes as a hydrogen source proceeds under base-free conditions, which indicates a different H-Si bond activation scenario. We probed the stoichiometric interaction between 1 and PhSiH3 by NMR and observed the formation of multiple hydride signals that gradually disappeared through the formation of molecular hydrogen [88]. We, therefore, carried out quantum mechanical calculations that might shed light on the mechanism. Scheme 3 represents the free energy profiles for two plausible pathways for the H-Si activation step. We first computed the metathetical hydride-chloride exchange, leaving the Ru(IV)-O bond intact, analogously to the one demonstrated in Scheme 2 (Scheme 3, right). According to the calculations, this thermodynamically slightly favored step (–6.8 kcal·mol−1) proceeds via a TS_1A located 44.1 kcal·mol−1 above 1, forming the intermediate Aeq, which may reorganize to a significantly more stable Aax. This isomerization makes this step exergonic by 17.9 kcal·mol−1. Next, we examined an alternative pathway to the formation of catalytically relevant Ru(IV)-H species via 1,2-addition of the H-Si bond across the Ru(IV)−O bond by analogy with the well-established MLC mechanism involving Ru-alkoxide/Ru-alkoxyl coordination switch as in Scheme 1 [89]. In this case, the computed reaction barrier was significantly lower (15.2 kcal·mol−1 above 1), but the reaction itself was found to be 3.5 kcal·mol−1 endergonic due to disrupting thermodynamically favorable tricyclic pincer architecture and despite the oxophilicity of Si. However, according to the calculations, coordination of the silyl ether sidearm to the Ru(IV) center regains stability by –30.4 kcal·mol−1. The latter pathway looks more realistic to us, given the lower reaction barrier and higher exergonicity of the Si-H activation; however, we cannot completely rule out the metathetic mechanism of the Ru-H formation. In conclusion, we have developed an efficient and chemoselective method of hydrosilylation of carbonyl compounds, carboxylic acids, esters, nitriles, and nitroarenes using a structurally well-defined RuIV catalyst. Furthermore, we demonstrated that high-valent hydride complexes can be regarded as “hard” nucleophiles, unlike more conventional low-valent counterparts. This unusual reactivity is underscored by the tolerance of the RuIV catalyst to nonpolar double bonds. Further experimental studies on the mechanism are underway. However, this process was not taken into consideration due to irrelevance with respect to catalysis.

coredata.dc:description: In this communication, we report on successfully applying a high-valent Ru(IV) bifunctional catalyst (1) for the hydrosilylation of carbonyl compounds, carboxylic acids, esters, nitriles, and nitroarenes. We found that high-valent hydride complexes can be regarded as “hard” nucleophiles, unlike more conventional low-valent counterparts. They demonstrate high chemoselectivity and affinity to reducing polar bonds over nonpolar ones. The scope and limitations of the method, as well as the plausible mechanism of the reaction, are described.
coredata.dc:title: A high-valent Ru-PCP pincer catalyst for hydrosilylation reactions
